data.title: People update: Ashton Kutcher, Demi Moore try to patch up their marriage in the great outdoors
data.meta_description: People update: Ashton Kutcher, Demi Moore try to patch up their marriage in the great outdoors
data.text:
What could be more serene and refreshing than a weekend camping trip in Santa Barbara — with Demi Moore, Ashton Kutcher, a Kabbalah instructor, some nosy campers armed with cameras and a tent full of bad karma?

Whether Kutcher and Moore really are trying save their marriage — or simply make it look as if they are, following his alleged affair with a 23-year-old girl in San Diego — the couple spent last weekend camping at Cachuma Lake, one day after attending Yom Kippur services Friday in Los Angeles. The couple’s Kabbalah instructor Yehuda Berg and Kutcher’s friend Eric Buterbaugh accompanied them.

Sounds romantic.

The foursome was pestered by neighboring campers who kept trying to snap photos of the beleaguered couple. Radar Online and Star magazine posted pictures of an agitated Moore trying to wave the shutterbugs away. According to Star, Moore was heard imploring an amateur paparazzo, “Please don’t take photos of me and my family. Please don’t expose this.”

Kutcher and Moore are not Jewish, but like many celebs, they follow the mystical faith of Kabbalah. The two reportedly attended a Kabbalah-based marriage counseling session seven weeks ago.

HAPPY BIRTHDAY DEAR BRUTAL DICTATOR, HAPPY BIRTHDAY TO YOU!: Hilary Swank and Jean-Claude Van Damme are facing a backlash for attending a lavish birthday party thrown for Chechen provincial leader Ramzan Kadyrov, the 35-year-old dictator accused of employing brutal measures to suppress Islamic separatists in his country.

The Hollywood Reporter says both actors were paid for their appearances at the Oct. 5 bash in Grozny, the Chechen capital. Several other stars, including Kevin Costner, Eva Mendes and Shakira, were also invited but declined, citing scheduling conflicts or other reasons.

Human Rights Watch called on the stars who attended the party to reimburse any money that they were paid to participate.

“Ramzan Kadyrov is linked to a litany of horrific human rights abuses. It’s inappropriate for stars to get paid to party with him,” the organization said.

Neither Swank, who previously had said she would not attend the event, nor Van Damme have commented on the matter.

Kadyrov was appointed president of Chechnya in 2007 by Russian leader Vladimir Putin. He replaced his father, Akhmad Kadyrov, a onetime Muslim cleric and separatist who did an about-face and aligned with Putin, his onetime enemy, to help bring Chechnya closer into Moscow’s fold before being assassinated. Now, Ramzan Kadyrov is seen as following in his father’s footsteps.

SERVE HIS PUBLIC OBLIGATIONS, HE WILL: A long time ago in a galaxy far, far away — OK, Marin County — “Star Wars” creator George Lucas weathered many a heated hearing at the Marin Civic Center over his Skywalker Ranch development. On Tuesday, he was back at Civic Center, this time for jury duty, reports the Marin Independent Journal.

In the end, the force was with Lucas — he was dismissed by the judge.

THIS AND THAT: Mitch Winehouse has reached a deal to write a book about his daughter, singer Amy Winehouse, publisher HarperCollins says. The book is due out next summer. Financial terms weren’t disclosed. Amy Winehouse died in July.

Javier Bardem has been cast as the villain in the next James Bond movie, he disclosed in an interview with Christiane Amanpour on “Nightline.” He declined to provide specifics, including whether he’ll revive that creepy haircut (brrr!!!) he used in “No Country For Old Men.”

HBO announced Tuesday that Michael Douglas and Matt Damon will star in “Behind the Candelabra,” a film about the relationship between Liberace (Douglas) and his younger live-in lover, Scott Thorson (Damon).

Adele led the pack in American Music Awards nominations announced Tuesday. The British singer garnered four bids, including artist of the year. Others receiving multiple nominations were Katy Perry, Lil Wayne, Lady Gaga, Rihanna, Taylor Swift and The Band Perry.

TODAY IN HISTORY

Today is Wednesday, Oct. 12, the 285th day of 2011. There are 80 days left in the year.

1492 (according to the Old Style calendar): Christopher Columbus arrived with his expedition in the present-day Bahamas.

1810: The German festival Oktoberfest was first held in Munich to celebrate the wedding of Bavarian Crown Prince Ludwig and Princess Therese of Saxe-Hildburghausen.

1870: Gen. Robert E. Lee died in Lexington, Va., at age 63.

1915: The Germans executed English nurse Edith Cavell in occupied Belgium during World War I.

1933: Bank robber John Dillinger escaped from a jail in Allen County, Ohio, with the help of his gang, who killed the sheriff, Jess Sarber.

1971: The rock opera “Jesus Christ Superstar” opened at the Mark Hellinger Theatre on Broadway.

2000: 17 sailors were killed in a suicide bomb attack on the destroyer USS Cole in Yemen.

2001: NBC announced that an assistant to anchorman Tom Brokaw had contracted the skin form of anthrax after opening a “threatening” letter to her boss containing powder. The United Nations and its secretary-general, Kofi Annan, won the Nobel Peace Prize.

BIRTHDAYS

Comedian-activist Dick Gregory (79), singer Sam Moore (76), broadcast journalist Chris Wallace (64),R&B singer Claude McKnight of Take 6 (49), actor Hugh Jackman (43), R&B singer Garfield Bright of Shai (42), country musician Martie Maguire of the Dixie Chicks (42), actor Kirk Cameron (41), Olympic gold medal skier Bode Miller (34), actor Marcus T. Paulk (25).

— Associated Press
